intro: Argylia uspallatensis, commonly known as the Uspallata bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the Andes mountains of South America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue or violet flowers. The plant typically grows in high-altitude environments, often in rocky or alpine regions. Its leaves are lanceolate and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are often hairy as well. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
